byline.original: By RACHEL ABRAMS and HIROKO TABUCHI

abstract: Death of Delia Robles in Riverside, Calif, due to faulty Takata air bag highlights how group of drivers who are second, third or even fourth owners of car are particularly vulnerable to vehicles with safety feature defects; Robles had bought 2001 Honda Civic at auto auction; federal law does not explicitly require sellers of used cars to fix problems linked to safety recalls, nor does it require sellers to disclose whether recalls have been implemented, and laws to strengthen regulations have languished in Congress.
lead_paragraph: Federal law does not mandate used-car sellers to tell buyers when a car has been recalled or to make necessary safety repairs, and the results can be deadly.
snippet: Federal law does not mandate used-car sellers to tell buyers when a car has been recalled or to make necessary safety repairs, and the results can be deadly....

headline.main: Used Cars Slip Past Recall Safeguards, Putting Drivers in Danger
headline.print_headline: Used Cars Elude Recall Repairs, Imperiling Lives
